ClfA has been clearly demonstrated to be a major virulence factor in many animal models. cytokines can upregulate or downregulate the production of ApoE in various tissue types. cytokines are believed to mediate its non-lipid associated functions through binding to cell-surface receptors. a novel peptide derivative of human ApoE could reproduce some of the biological properties of ApoE. we identified, using MS, ApoE as the major plasma protein to bind surface-coupled recombinant ClfA. we evaluated their binding to rClfA through CEWA and dot blot assays. an isogenic ClfA-deficient strain revealed statistically significant (P = 0.05) decreased binding to human ApoE compared to the wild-type ClfA-sufficient strain. ClfA-deficient strains are markedly less virulent, suggesting that ApoE binding to ClfA is unlikely to contribute to immunological control of S. aureus. future studies will focus on elucidating whether ClfA binding of ApoE enhances or inhibits S. aureus virulence. studies will focus on elucidating whether ClfA binding of ApoE enhances or inhibits S. aureus virulence and the mechanism by which this occurs. in vivo studies utilizing ApoE-knockout animal models and ClfA-deficient S. aureus strains are required to address the in-depth mechanism.
